en.title: Ansible – Lesson 12: Ansible Galaxy
en.subtitle: Using community roles, downloading roles and reusing automation with Ansible Galaxy

sections.heading: 1. What is Ansible Galaxy?
sections.content: Ansible Galaxy is a public repository where developers share Ansible roles for reuse.

sections.heading: 2. Why Use Ansible Galaxy?
sections.content: It saves time, avoids rewriting code and provides tested, community-maintained roles.

sections.heading: 3. Galaxy Website
sections.content: Roles are available at the official site: galaxy.ansible.com

sections.heading: 4. Searching for a Role
sections.content: You can search for roles on the Galaxy website by keyword like nginx, docker, mysql.

sections.heading: 5. Installing a Role
sections.content: Use command: ansible-galaxy install geerlingguy.nginx

sections.heading: 6. Default Role Install Location
sections.content: Roles are installed in ~/.ansible/roles or /etc/ansible/roles by default.

sections.heading: 7. Listing Installed Roles
sections.content: Use: ansible-galaxy list to see installed roles.

sections.heading: 8. Using Galaxy Role in Playbook
sections.content: Include the role using the roles keyword inside the playbook.

sections.heading: 9. Role Version Management
sections.content: You can install specific versions of roles to avoid breaking changes.

sections.heading: 10. requirements.yml File
sections.content: Multiple roles can be listed and installed using a requirements.yml file.

sections.heading: 11. Installing Roles from requirements.yml
sections.content: Use: ansible-galaxy install -r requirements.yml

sections.heading: 12. Best Practices with Galaxy
sections.content: Always read documentation, pin versions, test in staging before production use.

sections.heading: Lesson 12 Summary
sections.content: You learned what Ansible Galaxy is, how to install and use community roles and best practices.
